title: Cards
description: Cards contain content and actions that relate information about a subject.

contentChunks.htmlValue: There are three types of cards: elevated, filled, and outlined.

contentChunks.footer:
1. Elevated card
2. Filled card
3. Outlined card

contentChunks.htmlValue: Resources

TypeLinkStatus
DesignDesign kit (Figma)
Available
M2 guideline – CardsAvailable
ImplementationMDC-AndroidAvailable
Jetpack ComposeAvailable
FlutterAvailable
WebPlanned
Takeaways

• A card is identifiable as a single, contained unit
  • A card can hold anything from images to headlines, supporting text, buttons, lists, and other components
  • A card’s layout and dimensions depend on its contents. There is no one right way to make a card.
What's new

• Color: New color mappings and compatibility with dynamic color
  • Elevation: Lower elevation and no shadow by default
  • Types: Three official card types – elevated, filled, and outlined

Contents

Elevated card
Filled card
Outlined card
Layout

This section contains component attributes, token mappings, and default values for quick reference or building your own design files and implementations.

Contents

Usage

Responsive layout

contentChunks.altText: 3 example cards with headlines and body text

contentChunks.htmlValue: Usage

Use a card to display content and actions on a single topic.

Cards should be easy to scan for relevant and actionable information. Elements like text and images should be placed on cards in a way that clearly indicates hierarchy.

contentChunks.footer: Cards can display content and actions on a single topic.
contentChunks.altText: Example card containing text and images

contentChunks.htmlValue: Cards can serve as entry points into deeper levels of detail or navigation, such as a music album or details on an upcoming vacation.

contentChunks.footer: Card text and images show a clear hierarchy.
Use cards to display related information on a single subject.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Cards can be displayed together in a grid, vertical list, or carousel.

contentChunks.footer: Cards can be shown together.
Don't force content into cards when spacing, headlines, or dividers would create a simpler visual hierarchy.
contentChunks.altText: Example of cards filled with content

contentChunks.htmlValue:
There are 3 types of cards:

  1. Elevated
  2. Filled
  3. Outlined

Each provides the same legibility and functionality, so the type you use depends on style alone.

contentChunks.footer: 1. Elevated card  2. Filled card  3. Outlined card
Elevated cards have a drop shadow, providing more separation from the background than filled cards, but less than outlined cards.
Filled cards provide subtle separation from the background. This has less emphasis than elevated or outlined cards.
Outlined cards have a visual boundary around the container. This can provide greater emphasis than the other types.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Anatomy
The card container is the only required element in a card. Card layouts can vary to support the types of content they contain. Below is a common configuration of elements.

contentChunks.footer:
1. Container
2. Headline
3. Subhead
4. Supporting text
5. Image
6. Button
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of 8 parts of card anatomy

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Container

Card containers hold all card elements. Their size is determined by the space those elements occupy. Card elevation is expressed by the container.

The card container is the only required element of a card. All other elements are optional.

contentChunks.footer: Card size is determined by the elements it contains.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Content blocks

Card contents are grouped into blocks. Content can have different levels of visual emphasis depending on importance.

Card layouts vary to support the types of content they contain.

contentChunks.footer: Cards can contain headline, subhead, supporting text, media, and actions.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Dividers

Dividers can be used to separate regions in cards or to indicate areas of a card that can expand.

contentChunks.footer: Content that can be expanded should use full-width dividers (1).
contentChunks.altText: Example of divider running entire width of card

contentChunks.footer: Use inset dividers (1), which don’t run the full width of a card, to separate related content.
contentChunks.altText: Example of inset divider indented from edge of card

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Media

Thumbnail
Cards can include thumbnails for an avatar or logo.

Image
Cards can include photos, illustrations, and other graphics, such as weather icons.

Video
Cards can include video.

contentChunks.footer: Cards can contain thumbnails, images, and video.
contentChunks.altText: Example of card with thumbnail image

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Text

Headline
Headline text often communicates the subject of the card, such as the name of a photo album or article.

Subhead
Subheads are smaller text elements, such as an article byline or a tagged location.

 Supporting text
Supporting text includes body content, such as an article summary or a restaurant description.

contentChunks.footer: Headline, subhead, and supporting text in a card.
contentChunks.altText: Example of card container with several elements

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Layering text, icons, and images
It isn’t recommended to place text or icons on images. If doing so is necessary, ensure that the image used as background provides sufficient contrast to make the text meet accessibility standards.

Adding a translucent scrim or bounding shape beneath the text or icon can help ensure proper contrast.

contentChunks.footer: Ensure that text on images meets accessible contrast standards.
contentChunks.altText: Example of contrasting text on image

contentChunks.footer: When placing text or icons on images, consider using a bounding shape to ensure proper contrast.
contentChunks.altText: Example of icon within a bounding shape on image

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Actions

Primary action area
Cards can be one large touch target triggering an expanded detail screen.

contentChunks.footer: Cards can include a primary action area that expands into a full screen view.
contentChunks.altText: The action area of a card contains rich media and supporting text

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Buttons
Cards can include buttons for actions such as Learn more or Add to cart.

Icon buttons
Cards can include icon buttons for actions such as Save, Heart, or leaving a 4-star review.

Selection controls
Cards can also include chips, sliders, checkboxes, and other selection controls.

Linked text
There can be a link in the supporting text on a card.

contentChunks.footer: Cards can include multiple action areas containing buttons, links, and other controls.
contentChunks.altText: Supplemental text and actions at the bottom of the card

contentChunks.footer: Cards can contain icon buttons like stars to rate content.
Cards can contain choice chips within the action area.
Cards can contain a slider control within the action area.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Overflow menu
Overflow menus contain related actions. They are typically placed in the upper-right or lower-right corner of a card.

contentChunks.footer: Overflow menus are usually located in the upper-right or lower-right corner of a card.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Cards in a collection

Multiple cards can be grouped together into collections displayed in a grid, list, or carousel. By default, cards in a collection are coplanar, sharing the same resting elevation unless they are picked up or dragged.

contentChunks.footer: Multiple cards can be grouped into collections with a shared resting elevation.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Filtering and sorting
Card collections can be filtered in a variety of ways, including by date or alphabetical order. If a collection can be filtered, the filter must apply to each card in the collection. 

Filter or sorting options should be placed outside of the card collection.

contentChunks.footer: Card collections can be filtered in a variety of ways, including by date. Filter or sorting options (1) should be placed outside of the card collection.
contentChunks.altText: Example card collection with sort-by-date option

contentChunks.htmlValue: Organize card collections so that they are easy to use. Their layout affects how they are perceived.

contentChunks.footer: Place cards in a collection in a straightforward, easy-to-use manner.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Grid

Cards can be displayed together in a grid.
The default grid can be customized in code to show cards in staggered or mosaic grids.

contentChunks.footer: Customized mosaic grid.
Customized staggered grid.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Vertical list

Cards can be displayed together in a vertical list.

contentChunks.footer: Cards can be shown in a vertical list.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Carousel

Cards can be displayed together in a horizontal row or carousel.

contentChunks.footer: Cards displayed together in a horizontal row or carousel.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Responsive layout

As cards scale to adapt to different screen sizes, their position and alignment can also change.

Cards and their elements can align left, right, or center as the layout scales.

contentChunks.footer: Card position and alignment changes as the screen size changes.
contentChunks.altText: Example of card adapting to screen size

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Ergonomics

Adjust the layout of components to meet the ergonomic needs of large screen devices. For example, a horizontally oriented card on a mobile screen may become a larger, vertically oriented card on larger screens, lending more space to imagery and typography to fit the larger screen.

contentChunks.footer: Adjust component layout so content remains the main focus on large screens.
contentChunks.altText: Example of layout change accommodating content

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Visual presentation

To adjust the presentation of content-focused components, begin with spacing. Allow components like lists, cards, and images to optimize space while filling the region of a screen that suits a device breakpoint’s ergonomic needs.

contentChunks.footer: Spacing adjusts for components such as cards, lists, and images.
Example of the same card with two different orientations and element positioning.
contentChunks.altText: Example of same card with 2 different orientations and element positioning

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Column-based layouts

In mobile layouts, components such as lists or cards are stretched to fit the full width of the screen without compromising visual qualities or user experience. When designing for large screens, use multiple columns to display content. Avoid extending UI elements across the screen whenever possible. Groups of related cards can be rearranged to become horizontal rows or carousels, allowing for better content organization on larger screens.

contentChunks.footer: When designing for large screens, use multiple columns to display content.
contentChunks.altText: Example of related cards in a carousel

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Small screens

On smaller screens, consider swapping cards for lists, which can display images and text in a more compact form. Just make sure that controls, actions, and other component-specific elements are maintained.

contentChunks.footer: Certain devices or user contexts require different components to meet platform expectations.
contentChunks.altText: Example of small screen mobile layout

contentChunks.htmlValue: Behavior

Expanding

Cards use a container transform transition pattern to reveal additional content.

A card expands to fill the full screen using a parent-child transition.

contentChunks.footer: Cards use a container transform transition pattern to reveal additional content. Cards use a container transform transition pattern to reveal additional content.
Expand a card to reveal information.
Don’t scroll within a card to reveal information.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Navigation

Cards can use a forward and backward transition pattern to navigate between screens at consecutive levels of hierarchy. This pattern has a simpler motion style compared to container transform, which makes it suitable for common navigation transitions.

contentChunks.footer: Cards can use a forward and backward transition pattern to navigate between screens.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Gestures

Swipe

A swipe gesture can be performed on a single card at a time, anywhere on that card.

It can be used to:

  • Dismiss a card
  • Change the state of a card (such as flagging or archiving it)

contentChunks.footer: A card should only have 1 swipe action assigned to it.
contentChunks.altText: Example of card with 1 assigned swipe

contentChunks.footer: Cards should not contain content that can be swiped (such as an image carousel or pagination). Also, swipe gestures should not cause portions of cards to detach upon swiping.
contentChunks.altText: Example of swiped content on card

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Pick up and move

The pick-up-and-move gesture allows users to move and reorder cards in a collection.

contentChunks.footer: When moving a card, increase its elevation.When moving a card, increase its elevation.
Don’t let cards bump other elements out of the way. When a card is picked up, it appears in front of all elements (except app bars and navigation).

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Scrolling

Card content that is taller than the maximum card height is truncated and does not scroll, but can be displayed by expanding the height of a card. A card can expand beyond the maximum height of the screen, in which case the card scrolls within the screen.

contentChunks.footer: On a mobile device, cards can expand to reveal more content, scrolling within the screen. Content within cards doesn’t scroll.
On a mobile device, cards cannot internally scroll, as it could cause two scroll bars to be displayed.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Scrolling on desktop

On a desktop device, card content can expand and scroll within a card.

contentChunks.footer: On a desktop device, card content can expand and scroll within a card.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Accessibility

Focus

When navigating through focus points on a card, visit each focused element before moving to the next card.

For users that navigate solely using focus traversal (using a D-pad and keyboard), cards should have either a primary action or open a new screen containing primary and supplemental actions.

Accessibility guidelines coming soon

In progress: complete guidance for accessible interaction, keyboard navigation, labeling, and more. Learn more about accessibility.
